snippet: Experts said Israel’s refusal to confirm its attack was part of a strategy to offer face-saving ways to avoid escalation. But Syria may have undercut that effort.
abstract: Tensions over Israeli airstrike on Syrian territory increase as Syria delivers letter to United Nations declaring its right to self-defense and Israel's action is condemned by Iran, Hezbollah and Russia.

byline.original: By ANNE BARNARD and JODI RUDOREN
byline.contributor: Anne Barnard reported from Beirut, and Jodi Rudoren from Jerusalem. Reporting was contributed by Irit Pazner Garshowitz from Jerusalem, Ellen Barry from Moscow, Thomas Erdbrink from Tehran, and Alan Cowell from London.

lead_paragraph: Experts said Israel’s refusal to confirm its attack was part of a strategy to offer face-saving ways to avoid escalation. But Syria may have undercut that effort.

headline.seo: Syria’s Confirmation of Airstrike May Undercut Israel’s Strategy of Silence
headline.main: Syria Says It Has Right to Counterattack Israel
headline.print_headline: Syria Says It Has Right To Counterattack Israel

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
keywords.name: subject
